reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course covers the following 8 Chapters:

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Yu paces himself quite well, he actively answers questions in class and encourages students to answer his questions regarding certain topics. However, he still possesses certain glaring issues in his teachings.

My first main issue is the lack of recordings of the lecture, as it forces students to always attend his lectures, otherwise, they will miss important key ideas, solutions and proofs that are integral to solving certain exam questions. (P.S. I do not understand the focus on proofs in homework + exam questions when the course is focused on application). This is an issue since the Professor intentionally removes solutions to examples or even full proofs from the slides; if you do not have them, you better research now or else you cannot solve HW or Exam questions.

Additionally, the Professor intentionally refrains from posting the full lecture slides on a specific chapter, as such, I literally have to re-download the same lecture slides multiple times since it is always updated at the beginning of the lecture.

Lastly, his actual explanations of the concepts in class are quite vague and convoluted. They are not intuitive in the slightest and I am even more confused about the concept after his explanation. In essence, attend his class for solutions and proofs, and delve further into the explanations behind the content after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework Sets (4 x 10%)

Midterm (30%) - Mean: 54.05%, Median: 53%, Upper Quartile: 67%, Lower Quartile: 43%

Finals (30%) - Mean: 53.35%, Median: 55%, Upper Quartile: 65%, Lower Quartile: 43%

Homework should not be neglected as they contribute a significant portion to your overall grade. Getting below the mean within a Homework Set will set you back a sub-grade, and the Mean for each Homework Set is roughly ~95%.

Examinations are non-cumulative, as such the Midterm Examinations covers Chapter 1-4, while the Final Examination covers Chapter 5-8. All questions on the exam are variants of examples covered in class/homework or require conceptual understanding from lecture content. Therefore, by simply familiarising yourself with the slide's contents (especially the examples) and writing important equations in your cheatsheets, you can do decently in the exam. Exam questions will include proofs, hence, if the Professor focuses on deriving certain equations during lectures, be sure to record the procedure and understand it. Additionally, certain R code syntax questions will appear, be sure to note down each R Function and what each parameter is for during exam preparation (honestly, pretty stupid to ask about code syntax).

I scored below the mean in the Midterm, and above mean in the Finals. All my homework sets are around mean and my final grade was B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework sets are released monthly (in the middle of the month), ranging from 5-8 Long Questions. Each question requires careful calculations or proofs. All Homework Sets will require certain questions to be completed in R, so be sure to familiarise yourself with the syntax. Most homework would require 2-3 days to accomplish, so be sure to start early (do not be like me who stays up till 10 AM finishing a homework set).

Exam preparation will include preparing a sufficient cheatsheet containing notable equations, R syntax/code and procedures. It is important to spend some time familiarising yourself with the slide's examples as a variant of them might appear in the exam. Spend a good few days before the exam studying to perform decently.

Basic Statistics, where you can definitely handle without any rigorous stat knowledge background. If you did M1 in DSE, you should know a lot of the covered contents.

0. Introduction
- Basics definitions

1. Descriptive Statistics
- Box&Whisker, 3Ms, etc...

2. Probability
- Conditional Probi, **Baye's Thm**(very important in Midterm)

3. Random Variable (*POPULATION*)
i) Probability Mass, Density functions, Expected value E(x), Variance Var(x)
[with EASY single var Calculus]
ii) Distributions: Binomial, Poisson, ***Normal***
[learn how to identify when use which distribution]

4. Estimation
i)  Point Estimator: Biasness, Precision, Goodness of point est.
[Use many E(x), Var(x)]
ii) Interval Estimator: **Confidence Interval (C.I.)**
[Z,T,Chi-squared, basically refer to these 3 distribution tables]

------- Midterm -------

5. Hypothesis Testing:
i) Null(Ho) vs Alternative(H1), Type 1 & Type 2 Errors, Power
[Reject or NOT reject Ho, One-sided(>or<), Two-sided(!=), simple]
ii) Z,T,Chi-squared Test using Ho & H1
**[Concept same as C.I. (Chap 4ii)]**

6. Simple Linear Regression
- Linear regression
**[Use your calculator and programs]**

7. Two Sample Testing
- Concept same as Chap 5, but analyze 2 variables
[Added F Distribution and F tables]

8. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance)
- Compare significance difference in variances for >2 populations
[USE CALCULATOR PROGRAM, DON'T WASTE TIME!]

------- Final -------- (Cumulative)
